Seriously, from the moment you step onto the platform, it's a total immersion into Indian culture. Trust me, it’s way more than just getting from Point A to Point B.

unnormalised: So, you’re probably thinking, “Trains? Really?” But hold on a sec. Think of it like this: it's a rolling microcosm of India. You'll see everything – families sharing meals, chai wallahs hustling, and stunning landscapes whizzing by your window. Plus, you can snag a ticket for surprisingly cheap. I mean, a sleeper class ticket from Delhi to Mumbai can be as low as Rs. 800 if you book in advance. Try finding a flight for that price!

I mean, a sleeper class ticket from Delhi to Mumbai can be as low as rupee eight hundred if you book in advance. Try finding a flight for that price!

unnormalised: Now, let's talk specifics. There are tons of train options, from the super-fast Rajdhani and Shatabdi Express trains (think: slightly fancier and more expensive) to the more budget-friendly and slower passenger trains. Rajdhani might cost you around Rs. 3500 for the same Delhi to Mumbai route, but you get meals included and a faster travel time, around 16 hrs. The Passenger train could take almost 2 days! Don’t forget to check out IRCTC website to book your tickets.

There are tons of train options, from the super-fast Rajdhani and Shatabdi Express trains (think: slightly fancier and more expensive) to the more budget-friendly and slower passenger trains. Rajdhani might cost you around rupee three thousand five hundred for the same Delhi to Mumbai route, but you get meals included and a faster travel time, around sixteen hours. The Passenger train could take almost two days! Don’t forget to check out I-R-C-T-C website to book your tickets.

unnormalised: Booking is key, esp. during peak season (Diwali, summer holidays etc.). Seats get booked up FAST! I usually try to book at least 1 month in advance. You can use the IRCTC app or website. Pro-tip: Tatkal tickets (emergency quota) are available, but they're pricier and competitive to snag. Seriously, refreshing the page at 10:00 AM sharp on the day Tatkal opens is a sport in itself.

unnormalised: Okay, a few things to keep in mind for the ride: Pack light (relatively speaking – you’ll want your camera!), bring snacks (though the train food isn't half bad!), and always keep an eye on your belongings. Petty theft can happen, so be aware. Also, don’t forget to carry your ID. Aadhaar card, passport, voter ID – any government issued ID will do.

unnormalised: A lot of people complain about delays, and yeah, they happen. But honestly, that's part of the adventure, isn't it? Think of it as extra time to soak in the experience, chat with your fellow passengers, and people-watch. Remember that time my train was delayed by 6 hrs at a small station in UP? Ended up having the best chai and samosas with some locals.

unnormalised: So, ditch the plane and hop on a train! It's a unique, authentic, and unforgettable way to see India. Just remember to book ahead, pack smart, and embrace the chaos. Happy travels, bhai! You won't regret it. Just remember to check your PNR status regularly after booking to stay updated on any schedule changes.
